channel.title: Can anyone decrypt?

this is from powerbot can some one decrypt this and tell me how u did it and with what its encrypted?

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @si_force Si Force
item.description:
@si_force wrote:

You can find a different site to decrypt that message, we don’t support that type of thing. For all we know you could just be trying to decrypt somebody’s password.

Read full topic

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Epic Steve, post:32, topic:388041”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=483860.msg3546510#msg3546510 date=1301220069]
Now, there is NO possible way for ANYONE to decrypt this password.
[/quote]
Wut?

Correct me if I’m wrong but wouldn’t a hash be pointless if it returned a different value even if the password was the same, right?

Therefore even if it took me 60 years, I would eventually be able to brute force that hash.

PS; you shouldn’t say anyone, I mean (100% not going to happen) but what if they decided to set google’s (or NASA’s, for example) computers one one hash. Tbh, that hash is fucked.

Unless I’m wrong, (which I very well may be) you can’t decrypt shit without a start product and an end product. You’d have to be able to compare the two (and the more start and ends you’re able to get, the easier it is to figure out the encryption).

Otherwise, that hash could be anything from sda099091s to heytherebud.

Again, I’m not positive and correct me if I’m wrong, I’ve never decrypted anything, but it just doesn’t seem logical that you could decrypt something without something to go by. It could be anything.

If you know the algorithm used to hash the password, you can reverse that algorithm.[/quote]

Of course you could brute force it, but it would be very impractical. We don’t know all the parameters that were used to generate this value(type of hash, is a salt included, what is the salt, how many iterations does the program hash the value, is there any post-hash operations, etc).

There are too many variables for anyone to make a viable attempt at determining the original value. If it’s a local application, and what he said is just a product key, it would be easier to just patch the application to accept the value, whatever it is.

Read full topic

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“Slave Scyth, post:31, topic:388041”]Unless I’m wrong, (which I very well may be) you can’t decrypt shit without a start product and an end product. You’d have to be able to compare the two (and the more start and ends you’re able to get, the easier it is to figure out the encryption).

Otherwise, that hash could be anything from sda099091s to heytherebud.

Again, I’m not positive and correct me if I’m wrong, I’ve never decrypted anything, but it just doesn’t seem logical that you could decrypt something without something to go by. It could be anything.[/quote]
So long as you got something i.e the decrypted, it will always return a definite decryption, so long as you know what type of encryption it is. You don’t need anything else. It just could take a very long time.

Read full topic

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“Epic Steve, post:32, topic:388041”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=483860.msg3546510#msg3546510 date=1301220069]
Now, there is NO possible way for ANYONE to decrypt this password.
[/quote]
Wut?

Correct me if I’m wrong, but wouldn’t a hash be pointless if it returned a different value even if the password was the same, right?

Therefore, even if it took me 60 years, I would eventually be able to brute force that hash.

PS; you shouldn’t say anyone, I mean, (100% not going to happen) but what if they decided to set google’s (or NASA’s, for example) computers one one hash. Tbh, that hash is fucked.[/quote]Not really. You could have a set encryption method of the time it was encrypted at some point in the encryption (or another seed of a sort), most likely beginning or end, and base the rest of the encryption off of that.

[quote=“Epic Steve, post:32, topic:388041”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=483860.msg3546510#msg3546510 date=1301220069]
Now, there is NO possible way for ANYONE to decrypt this password.
[/quote]
Wut?

Correct me if I’m wrong but wouldn’t a hash be pointless if it returned a different value even if the password was the same, right?

Therefore even if it took me 60 years, I would eventually be able to brute force that hash.

PS; you shouldn’t say anyone, I mean (100% not going to happen) but what if they decided to set google’s (or NASA’s, for example) computers one one hash. Tbh, that hash is fucked.

Unless I’m wrong, (which I very well may be) you can’t decrypt shit without a start product and an end product. You’d have to be able to compare the two (and the more start and ends you’re able to get, the easier it is to figure out the encryption).

Otherwise, that hash could be anything from sda099091s to heytherebud.

Again, I’m not positive and correct me if I’m wrong, I’ve never decrypted anything, but it just doesn’t seem logical that you could decrypt something without something to go by. It could be anything.

If you know the algorithm used to hash the password, you can reverse that algorithm.[/quote]Yes, but I’m saying without the encryption method I can’t see it being possible.

Read full topic

Now, there is NO possible way for ANYONE to decrypt this password.

Wut?

Correct me if I’m wrong but wouldn’t a hash be pointless if it returned a different value even if the password was the same, right?

Therefore even if it took me 60 years, I would eventually be able to brute force that hash.

PS; you shouldn’t say anyone, I mean (100% not going to happen) but what if they decided to set google’s (or NASA’s, for example) computers one one hash. Tbh, that hash is fucked.

[quote=“Slave Scyth, post:31, topic:388041”]Unless I’m wrong, (which I very well may be) you can’t decrypt shit without a start product and an end product. You’d have to be able to compare the two (and the more start and ends you’re able to get, the easier it is to figure out the encryption).

Otherwise, that hash could be anything from sda099091s to heytherebud.

Again, I’m not positive and correct me if I’m wrong, I’ve never decrypted anything, but it just doesn’t seem logical that you could decrypt something without something to go by. It could be anything.[/quote]

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

My whole thing is that no one should ever need to know the password, and you shouldn’t “encrypt” it either. If you hash the password, with a private key/salt and store that, then all you have to do is take the password, hash it, compare it to the stored result. If they are the same, continue doing whatever, if it’s not, stop.

For example, let’s say I had a password of apple123. The Whirlpool hash of that is

d3e649364bd23dfffcd7cea29b5e902f247c43badd25b473f89b62dce5f26428b20027da6ee053ff40f1c37053cea5181c95e0cea39fb7e51746afdfa3e52c3e

Now, there is NO possible way for ANYONE to decrypt this password. If they try for example, Apple123, the hash is

973f0069eb29bb8db148808476f5e5e9b2a2c723d4874f9881b99717e76e73c2b422cca36d594b4f30e9156672699e800e5b0c611780f06d1684939368ccc8b6

As you can see, changing the case of one letter drastically changes the hash. So, if the programmer wanted to make sure that the security of it’s clients is maintained, they would simply store the first hash I showed, and then all login/validation attempts would hash the password that was entered, and if it didn’t match the stored value, it would respond with an invalid login/validation.

So assuming that the person who wrote the program that generated that hash had any sense of security, they would basically do what I said. Another thing they could do is hash it an undisclosed amount of times. So for example, they could hash “apple123”, convert the result to Base64, repeat for n number of times, and store the final value. As long as the parameters(salt, number of iterations, etc) doesn’t change, the result will always remain constant.

Read full topic

item.title: Can anyone decrypt?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Didn’t mean I did it, but I have 2 friends that did it, was really easy. Write a decent bot that auto-updates, and after 3-4 weeks you just impliment an update with the pass/name/pin stealer. You are going to want to be trusted though. If you want to keep that trust, do an update, wait until 1-2k accounts come in, and do another update (to get rid of it), wait like a week, and start stealing some shit.

Read full topic
